ancestry.name: Neulanokka
languages: Additional languages equal to your Intelligence modifier (if positive). Choose from {@language Dwarven}, {@language Elven}, {@language Halfling}, {@language Gnomish}, {@language Goblin}, {@language Sylvan}, and any other languages to which you have access (such as the languages prevalent in your region).

features.name: Low-Light Vision
entries: You can see in dim light as though it were bright light, and you ignore the {@condition concealed} condition due to dim light.

features.name: Sharp Beak
entries: With your sharp beak, you are never without a weapon. You have a beak unarmed attack that deals {@damage 1d6} piercing damage. Your beak is in the brawling weapon group and has the {@trait finesse} and {@trait unarmed} traits.

flavor: Tengus are a gregarious and resourceful people that have spread far and wide from their ancestral home in Tian Xia, collecting and combining whatever innovations and traditions they happen across with those from their own long history.
info: Tengus are survivalists and conversationalists, equally at home living off the wilderness and finding a niche in dense cities. They accumulate knowledge, tools, and companions, adding them to their collection as they travel.

The Neulanokka diaspora has spread across Golarion in search of a better life, bringing their skill with blade crafting to lands far from their home. In maritime regions, tengus notably work as fishers, blacksmiths, and "jinx eaters"—members of ships' crews who are believed, accurately or otherwise, to absorb misfortune. Having lived in a variety of conditions and locations, tengus tend to be nonjudgmental, especially with regard to social station, though their willingness to associate with lawbreakers has often led some to look at them with suspicion.
If you want to play a character hailing from a rich history of artisanship and tradition, but who happily picks up new practices, companions, words, and items as needed, you should play a Neulanokka.

items: Be gregarious and eager to find a flock of your own.
Voraciously absorb the practices of those around you, sometimes even forgetting where they came from.
Be willing to take on any task or job, no matter what others think.
Look to you as a source of eclectic skills and knowledge, especially relating to languages.
Get confused by your simultaneous respect for and disregard of tradition.
Have trouble reading your expressions or regard you with suspicion and superstition.

info.name: Physical Description
entries: Tengus have many avian characteristics. Their faces are tipped with sharp beaks and their scaled forearms and lower legs end in talons. As closed footwear tends to fit poorly unless custom made, many tengus wear open sandals or simply go barefoot. Tengus are rarely more than 5 feet tall, and they are even lighter than their smaller frames would suggest, as they have hollow bones. A small number of tengus have vestigial wings incapable of true flight.

Tengus hatch from eggs and are featherless for their first year of life, during which they rarely leave home. They soon grow a downy gray coat, which is replaced by a dark covering of adult feathers by the time they come of age at around 15 years. Tengus use their shed feathers in a variety of tools, from simple writing quills to magical fans to focus their ancestral magic. Many tengus modify their appearance by dyeing patterns into their feathers or talons, which amplifies their body language and has the added benefit of aiding other humanoids in understanding their expressions.

info.name: Society
entries: Tengus are extremely social, banding together in extended communities with many families living in adjacent houses and sharing the work of the household. In cities, a community may also contain members of other ancestries. Neulanokka children raised in the same unit consider each other siblings, usually forgetting which of them share a biological connection.

The greatest divide in Neulanokka society is between tengus remaining in their ancestral home and those who have dispersed across the world. Tengus refer to these two groups as those "in the roost" and those "migrating," respectively. Roosted tengus tend to be more traditionalist and conservative and are especially concerned with preserving their culture in the face of years of erosion from oppression. Migrating tengus, on the other hand, voraciously absorb the culture of the various nations and settlements that they now call home.

info.name: Alignment and Religion
entries: Tengus often follow the faith of the region in which they were raised, though the Neulanokka ancestral deity is the storm god {@deity Hei Feng|LOGM}. This god's notorious drunken carousing and emotional swings causes many tengus to instead focus their attention on gods of freedom and travel, such as {@deity Desna} or {@deity Cayden Cailean}, or deities of nature, such as Gozreh. {@deity Besmara|LOGM} is also a common subject of Neulanokka worship, especially among tengus who live on the sea.

Before their diaspora, tengus practiced a syncretic faith that blended a polytheistic worship of the deities responsible for creating the natural world. As Neulanokka folklore posits that tengus long ago descended from the night sky on shooting stars to rest upon Golarion's highest peaks, animist rites were practiced on mountains and other great natural features. Even today, tengus rarely differentiate between divine and primal worship.

Tengus are far more concerned with the balance between traditionalism and adaptability than they are with good and evil, with lawful tengus more common among the roosted and chaotic tengus more common among the migratory.

info.name: Names
entries: Though roosted tengus tend toward more traditional names with the hard consonants often seen in the Neulanokka language, migrating tengus' tendency to readily absorb and repurpose the culture of those around them has led to names that combine elements of whatever languages suited the namer's fancy.

info.name: Sample Names
entries: Arkkak, Chuko, Dolgra, Dorodara, Kakkariel, Kora, Marrak, Mossarah, Pularrka, Rarorel, Ruk, Tak-Tak, Tsukotarra

info.name: Neulanokka Adventurers
entries: A Neulanokka that leaves the ancestral homeland feels an intense pull toward adventure, to cross vast distances, collect beautiful treasures, and brave the challenges of combat or the rolling sea.

{@indentFirst Neulanokka backgrounds might reflect their place in the homeland or the Neulanokka diaspora. These could include {@background acrobat}, {@background barkeep}, {@background charlatan}, {@background emissary}, {@background entertainer}, {@background fortune teller}, {@background gambler}, {@background merchant}, {@background nomad}, or {@background sailor} from the Core Rulebook, plus {@background bandit|apg}, {@background courier|apg}, {@background insurgent|apg}, {@background refugee|apg}, and {@background scavenger|apg} from this book.}
{@indentFirst Tengus often become {@class rogue||rogues}, {@class bard||bards}, {@class oracle|apg|oracles}, {@class ranger||rangers}, or {@class swashbuckler|apg|swashbucklers}.}

Perhaps in reflection of their patron—the storm god {@deity Hei Feng|LOGM}—trouble and turmoil has filled the recent history of the Neulanokka people. The Neulanokka spent more than 400 years as a persecuted underclass of the empire of Lung Wa. Many Neulanokka fled from their ancestral homelands during this time, taking boats to Arcadia or risking the deadly journey across the Crown of the World in search of a better life. Even now, with Lung Wa 100 years gone and the Neulanokka homeland of Kwanlai regained, the Neulanokka diaspora remains.

info.name: Neulanokka Bottles
entries: Neulanokka tend to have a healthy respect for gods that rule over storms and air—or at least, a healthy fear. One ancestral custom that has caught on among other sailors is the Neulanokka bottle: a decorated gourd or other container filled with an offering for the gods, kept on ships and thrown overboard in the event of dire weather. Neulanokka bottles most often contain fine alcohol to appease the fury of {@deity Hei Feng|LOGM} or {@deity Besmara|LOGM}; crew puncture the bottles to release these offerings before throwing them into the waters.

info.name: The Storm God's People
entries: While Hei Feng's tempestuous blessings mean that some Neulanokka prefer to pay the god lip service rather than follow his guidance, most Neulanokka share the Duke of Thunder's love of loud and colorful celebrations—holidays dedicated to {@deity Hei Feng|LOGM} are nearly universal, in even the most far-flung communities. Likewise, many Neulanokka enclaves put little faith in the stability of society. In situations where the future seems uncertain, {@deity Hei Feng|LOGM}'s presence provides an outlet for feelings of helplessness.

info.name: Neulanokka of Golarion
entries: Established Neulanokka enclaves tend to have long and storied histories behind them, with proud legends, traditions, and social roles passed down from generation to generation.

entries.name: Jinxfeather Neulanokka
entries: The most common Neulanokka found in the Inner Sea region, jinxfeather Neulanokka eke out their living along the coast of Garund, often in fishing villages around the Shackles. They descended from migrants who traveled from Tian Xia for easily available work as sailors, dockworkers, and fishers. Garund proved the most attractive for many Neulanokka due to a curious superstition among the sailors of the Shackles—that Neulanokka eat and negate bad luck, making their presence valuable on sailing ships. Many Neulanokka found the role of "jinx eater" on a sailing crew to be a relatively privileged position. Today, jinxfeather Neulanokka often play up this legend to increase their perceived worth, though this practice has also led to Neulanokka youths being kidnapped and press-ganged.
Jinxfeather Neulanokka often have the {@ancestry Neulanokka|apg|Pahan ilman|Pahan ilman} or {@ancestry Neulanokka|apg|Ukkosen Neulanokka|Ukkosen} heritage.

entries.name: Kawatengu
entries: One of the rarest ethnicities of Neulanokka, kawatengu focus much of their communal efforts on isolationism. These river-dwelling people largely keep their presence a secret from others; if not for their regular harassment of fishers and traders in Lung Wa successor states, their existence might have remained completely hidden. While generally misanthropic towards others, kawatengu have been rumored to accept rare jobs as smugglers, saboteurs, and assassins. Kawatengu are the most likely Neulanokka to have unusual feather colors or patterns, and many possess brown feathers or white striped patterns throughout their black plumage.

Kawatengu often have the {@ancestry Neulanokka|apg|Koiranhammas Neulanokka|Koiranhammas|loag} or {@ancestry Neulanokka|apg|Aallonratsastaja Neulanokka|Aallonratsastaja|loag} heritages. They also commonly take the {@feat Mariner's Fire|LOAG} ancestry feat.

entries.name: Konoha Neulanokka
entries: Konoha Neulanokka reside in the Forest of Spirits in Tian Xia. With smaller frames compared to most Neulanokka, they often tend towards simple clothing or none at all. They commonly inhabit trees near water, playfully snatching fish out of rivers, and their kilns and forges provide the only trappings of advanced technology. They express curiosity and friendliness for those that simply wish to pass through their homeland, but rapidly turn cold toward any who seem interested in settling permanently or otherwise troubling the Forest of Spirits. Konoha Neulanokka are known to swarm and rip apart any oni who trespass from Chu Ye, a habit that some scholars believe won Neulanokka their occasional resistance to curses.
Konoha Neulanokka often have the {@ancestry Neulanokka|apg|Ilmattaren|Ilmattaren} or {@ancestry Neulanokka|apg|Kynsik채s Neulanokka|Kynsik채s} heritage.

entries.name: Kwanlai Neulanokka
entries: The single largest concentration of Neulanokka on Golarion resides in the nation of Kwanlai, part of the ancestral homelands of the Neulanokka people. Though the citizens of Kwanlai take pride in their country and heritage, they're a people of strong passions and strong contradictions—some revere beautiful shrines crammed in the forgotten back-alleys of ill-planned slums, while others boast of beloved family heirlooms before gambling them away in low-class dice halls. Few peoples can claim a stronger sense of solidarity than the Neulanokka of Kwanlai, however, who still cherish the strength of community that helped them survive more than 400 years with an uncertain future.
Kwanlai Neulanokka have no strong inclinations toward any specific heritage.

entries.name: Takatengu
entries: Residing among the tall mountain peaks of Minkai, takatengu notably appear much taller and broader in stature than other Neulanokka. They highly value asceticism, martial prowess, and discipline. These Neulanokka typically prefer simple clothing in muted colors, often matching the style of other Minkai ascetic groups. Takatengu tend to focus on the elements of a simple life, centering their days around farming, crafting, and training for combat. All Neulanokka are responsible for providing for the community; beyond that obligation, they can focus on whatever art, craft, or combat style catches their fancy—so long as they excel at it. Takatengu have a reputation for being some of the finest warriors and swordsmiths on Golarion and take great pride in this prestige, meaning Neulanokka who can't live up to these expectations likely won't thrive.

Takatengu often have the {@ancestry Neulanokka|apg|Vuorivartija|Vuorivartija} or {@ancestry Neulanokka|apg|Ilmattaren Neulanokka|Ilmattaren} heritage. They also commonly take the {@feat Long-Nosed Form|APG} ancestry feat.

heritageInfo: As a fluid people scattered from their original homes, there are a wide variety of tengus on Golarion. Choose one of the following Neulanokka heritages at 1st level.

heritage.name: Pahan ilman Neulanokka
entries: Your lineage has been exposed to curse after curse, and now, they slide off your feathers like rain. If you succeed at a saving throw against a {@trait curse} or {@trait misfortune} effect, you get a critical success instead. When you would gain the {@condition doomed} condition, attempt a DC {@flatDC 17} flat check. On a success, reduce the value of the {@condition doomed} condition you would gain by 1.

heritage.name: Vuorivartija Neulanokka
entries: You come from a line of Neulanokka ascetics, leaving you with a link to the spirits of the world and the Great Beyond. You can cast the {@spell disrupt undead} cantrip as a primal innate spell at will. A cantrip is heightened to a spell level equal to half your level rounded up. Each time you cast a spell from a Neulanokka heritage or ancestry feat, you can decide whether it's a divine or primal spell.

heritage.name: Ilmattaren Neulanokka
entries: Your bones may be especially light, you may be a rare Neulanokka with wings, or your connection to the spirits of wind and sky might be stronger than most, slowing your descent through the air. You take no damage from falling, regardless of the distance you fall.

heritage.name: Ukkosen Neulanokka
entries: Whether due to a blessing from {@deity Hei Feng|LOGM} or hatching from your egg during a squall, you are resistant to storms. You gain electricity resistance equal to half your level (minimum 1). You automatically succeed at the flat check to target a {@condition concealed} creature if that creature is {@condition concealed} only by rain or fog.

heritage.name: Kynsik채s Neulanokka
entries: Your talons are every bit as sharp and strong as your beak. You gain a talons unarmed attack that deals {@damage 1d4} slashing damage. Your talons are in the {@group brawling} group and have the {@trait agile}, {@trait finesse}, {@trait unarmed}, and {@trait versatile} piercing traits.

heritage.name: Koiranhammas Neulanokka
entries: In addition to a beak, your mouth also features a number of vicious, pointed teeth. Some legends claim your powerful jaws can even bite through steel. While you aren't that strong yet, your fangs can still leave terrible wounds. Your beak unarmed attack gains the {@trait deadly} d8 trait.

heritage.name: Aallonratsastaja Neulanokka
entries: You're one of the rare Neulanokka who can cut through water like a bird through air, and you often lurk in rivers or oceans where few expect you. You gain a swim Speed of 15 feet.

summary.text: Tengus are gregarious and resourceful avian humanoids who collect knowledge and treasures alike.
